title: How to write the date in Japanese - Quora

response.answer_text: The other two answers are great, but not complete. They write dates a few different ways here in Japan. Broadly, we can divide these into Japanese style and Western style. Western Style This is the same as most of the rest of the world uses, the standard Gregorian calendar. Most of the time they will style this using year/month/day format. So, for example, today’s date is 6 Nov 2019, and this would be written 2019/11/6. This might be written with slashes or it might be written with kanji. In that case, our example date would become ２０１９年１１月６日. Now occasionally you will find other ways of writing it, but that is the usual. Also of note is that documents written for foreigners may use either UK or US style when written out. So, in our example, 6 Nov 2019, or Nov 6, 2019. But when they shorten it to slashes, it will often use US style, so 11/6/2019, not 6/11/2019. Japanese Style This will use the name of the current historic era and will count from the enthronement of the emperor of that era. For example, we got a new emperor this year and his era is named 令和 (Reiwa), so today’s date (6 Nov 2019) would be styled 6 Nov Reiwa 1. This will still follow the year month day format, so it’d generally be styled 令和１年１１月６日 Combination You might often see it combined, so you’d see something like this (令和１年)２０１９年１１月６日 Forms also often seem to ask both dates. Whenever I have to fill out a form for my son’s school, for instance, they want both the Japanese year and the Western year for all dates. For many dates you just memorize it. For example, I was born in 1978, which is Shōwa (昭和) 53. I also have the Japanese years for my wife and kids memorized, which pretty much covers all the dates I need for official paperwork. Worth noting, usage of the Japanese system is fading in many businesses. Any government paperwork you do, however, will still use it.

The order is always Year-Month-Date. When adding which day it is, brackets+abbreviation comes after the date like （水）. With the Christian era 2019年11月6日 2019/11/06 2019/11/6 二〇一九年十一月六日 With 元号(Japanese era) Official documents such as documents published by the government and legal documents tend to be in this style. 令和元年十一月六日 We don't write “令和1年”平成29年3月31日 Versions without a specific date 令和元年十一月末日 / 2019年11月末日 = November 30th 令和元年十一月吉日 = On a good day in November 吉日 is used in written social communications like invitation to wedding, seasonal greetings, and so on.

Japanese standard is not, as another answer claims, the same as other countries. In Japan, it goes from biggest to smallest: Year, Month, Day. So today would be 2019年7月18日. You can see the kanji for year (nen, in case you need for phonetic entry to get the kanji), month (gatsu, same as for moon), and day (nichi, same as for sun) there. However, the year can also be written as 1年, because this is the Year One of the reign of the Reiwa Emperor. Both international year and reign year are acceptable. Side note: Addresses also go biggest-to-smallest: Nation, prefecture, county, city, ward, neighborhood, block, building, apartment, person’s name—leaving out any that aren’t necessary. (For example, since I live in a major city, I never bother writing my prefecture or county, since to zip code and city name will be plenty for the post office to route mail to my city.)

if they are using the western caledar, they usually follow the European model and write the Day, then the month, then the year, so July 10th, 2019 is 10/7/19 But they often use the Japanese calendar for the year, which is based on the year of the current Emperor’s reign. This system just started anew this year with the abdication of the Emperor Heisei and the promotion of Emperor Reiwa to the throne. So the date for Nov 5, 2019 is written as 1/11/5 with the year coming first. Nov 5, 2018 would be written 30/11/5 with the kanji for “Heisei” 平成 preceding the number 30, the last full year of Emperor Heisei’s reign. Hope that helps.

Year/month/day. They use numbers with simple kanji to indicate what the number represents :) . Kanji - Kanji meaning 年 - Year 月 - Month 日 - Day . They use the 12 month calendar, with numbers 1 through 12 representing January through December. 2019年11月4日 = November 4th 2019 Doesn't get much simpler than that!

The Japanese typically write in YYYY/MM/DD format, and follow each number with the kanji denoting the significance of the number (i.e. 年 [ねん] for year, 月 [げつ] for month, 日 [にち] for day). Additionally in some documents and settings they still use the Japanese era calendar scheme, which is based on the reign of an emperor. In this system, it is currently the year Reiwa 1(令和1). Prior to that, it was the year Heisei 31 (平成31), up until the abdication of emperor Akihito.
